docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Destrix is not created yet. This documentation is more of a concept, and shown demos are POC's.

docs.title: Welcome to Destrix Documentation
docs.text: Welcome, developers! We’re thrilled to have you here. Destrix is your ultimate admin and moderation companion, specifically crafted with developers in mind. We understand the intricacies and challenges faced in building immersive, engaging, and safe gaming environments. That's why Destrix is engineered to be flexible, seamless, and non-disruptive, ensuring your game’s integrity while enhancing the user experience.

docs.title: Who We Are
docs.text: Destrix is a developer-centric admin system forged to simplify and empower your Roblox development journey. We amalgamate efficiency, flexibility, and power to offer an intuitive interface and a rich set of functionalities that make admin tasks a breeze. Our tools are tailored to be non-intrusive, ensuring that the natural flow and design of your game remain untarnished.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Adaptable: Easily customizable to fit the unique needs, challenges, and constraints of your game.
  • Efficient: Execute admin and moderation tasks with speed and precision.
  • Secure: Built with robust security protocols to safeguard your gaming environment.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text: Dive into our comprehensive list of commands, each designed to offer you unparalleled control and moderation power, ensuring that you’re always in command.

docs.title: DAX
docs.text: The Destrix API Module (DAX, also referred to as DAXM) is module that helps scripts to easily interact with and control Destrix from the server side.

docs.title: DAXI
docs.text: Explore DAXI, where innovation meets intuition. A tool that’s not just about getting things done but about redefining what’s possible in the world of game moderation. A powerful tool for developers to integrate their own models and systems seamlessly with Destrix.

docs.title: Extension Docs
docs.text: Get the insights, guides, and tips you need to extend and enhance the capabilities of Destrix. Your journey to creating a safe, engaging, and immersive gaming world just got easier.

docs.title: Join The Community
docs.text:
Become part of a community of passionate, like-minded developers. Share, learn, collaborate, and innovate, as we together shape the future of gaming on Roblox.

Join on  Discord

Happy Developing!

Read our Installation Guide to quickly get Destrix for your games!

docs.title: All Commands
docs.text:
Destrix has a lot of new and exciting commands, this is a large list of what those commands are and what they do, by category.

Command Parameters Category Summary Default Permission Level /ban Player : player, Reason : string, Moderator Note : string Utility Ban a player. 1

This page takes a while to create, for now you can check the sidebar for all the commands.

docs.title: What are parameters?
docs.text: Parameters are specified information a command asks for. Parameters are also referred to and may be known as Arguments, especially in other systems. For example, the /ban uses parameters: Player, Reason, and Moderator Note. So, the command looks like /ban Username, without parameters, it would just look like /ban with no username.

docs.title: Parameter Types
docs.text:
Incomplete documentation

"Parameter Types" documentation is not yet finished. Please wait until Destrix is confirmed.

docs.title: Player
docs.text:
Probably the most simplest of the complex type of command, the player. Parameters of this type can expect a Player class returned. In a command, if you wanted to provide @DestrixApp, you could simply type /command @DestrixApp, /command DestrixApp, or type /command d (if no one else is in the server who's name starts with a d).

@me

You may recognise that in some command specifics that the default value of parameter type "player" is sometimes @me, this will default to whatever use trigged the command. This is what a player type will be set to if no parameter is provided.

docs.title: Number
docs.text: Simply a number. Int, float, or a double. For example, you can type /command 0, /command 0.00, or /command -0 and the outcome will all be the same; 0. Command creators can specify or lock a command to an integer by chaning number to number:i, which converts it to an integer automatically.

docs.title: String
docs.text: Words. Just type /command Your text here, and Your text here will be passed. Alternatively, you can also use /command "Your text here" if you wish. If two string parameters are required next to eachother, type the command as so: /command Your text here||Your 2nd text here, and two separate strings (Your text here and Your 2nd test here) will be provided.

docs.title: Time
docs.text: More complex than expected, but also simple at the same time. Type /command 120s, /command 120, /command 2m and 120 will be provided. For longer times, use /command 2d-0h-3m-4s. That was simpler than I thought.

docs.title: Color
docs.text:
You can either type, A) a color shortcut (e.g. white), a HEX color (e.g. #FFF or #FFFFFF), or in RGB format (e.g. 255,255,255).

Color Shortcuts

Color Shortcuts:

Shortcut Standard HEX RGB Additional Notes white #FFFFFF 255,255,255 black #000000 0,0,0 dark-red #8B0000 139,0,0 red #FF0000 255,0,0 crimson #DC143C 220,20,60 firebrick #B22222 178,34,34 green #FF0000 255,0,0 dark-green #006400 0,100,0 forest-green #228B22 34,139,34 olive #808000 128,128,0 lime #32CD32 50,205,50 blue #0000FF 0,0,255 navy #000080 0,0,128 royal-blue #4169E1 65,105,225 sky-blue #87CEEB 135,206,235 steel-blue #4682B4 70,130,180 purple #800080 128,0,128 indigo #4B0082 75,0,130 dark-orchid #9932CC 153,50,204 plum #DDA0DD 221,160,221 lavender #E6E6FA 230,230,250 pink #FFC0CB 255,192,203 magenta #FF00FF 255,0,255 This color is hideous. yellow #FFFF00 255,255,0 gold #FFD700 255,215,0 goldenrod #DAA520 218,165,32 khaki #F0E68C 218,165,32 lemon-chiffon #FFFACD 255,250,205 orange #FFA500 255,156,0 brown #A52A2A 165,42,42 cyan #00FFFF 0,255,255 gray #808080 128,128,128 silver #C0C0C0 192,192,192 teal #008080 0,128,128 peach #FFDAB9 255,218,185 coral #FF7F50 255,127,80

docs.title: Filtered String (string:f)
docs.text: Works the same as a string, except it filters the string for using input.

docs.title: Material
docs.text: Expects a material (Enum.Material.{MaterialName}), e.g. /command {MaterialName}.

docs.title: User
docs.text: A user ID or username, for example: /command 655331725 or /command @Wolf1te.

docs.title: Two string parameters next to eachother.
docs.text: If a command requires or can recieve 2 or more string paramaters consecutively, separate them with '||'. For example, /ban @1Wolfite This is the reason||This is the moderator note.

About

(/about)
docs.text:
Software

|

0

|

Added 0.1.2

A shortcut to open the Destrix about page.

docs.title:
Ban

(/ban)
docs.text:
Utility

,

Moderation

|

4

|

Added 0.1.2

| ban

The /ban command bans the specified player/s, with the default length being permanent. Other commands achievve similar yet different effects. Such as /temp-ban, which bans a player temporarily, or /kick, which kicks the player and allows them to rejoin after being disconnected.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
Name Type Required Default Description Player player nil The player you want to ban Reason string nil The reason the player will see (filtered). Moderator Note string "No note provided" What other moderators will see when looking at the bans.

/ban {player} {reason} {moderator-note} | /ban @Roblox Making annoying updates||For the greater good

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• /server-ban
  • /tban
  • /kick
  • /bans
  • /limits

docs.title:
Message

(/m)
docs.text:
Utility

|

3

|

Added 0.1.2

| message, m

/message (or /m for short) displays a message on all users' screens in the server with the specified text. The message usually lasts 5 seconds, but can vary depending on the length of the text. The text is filtered by Roblox and the maximum character limit is 180.

Arguments: msg : string

The /poll command is currently in beta and may malfunction. It is currently only available to plus subscribers.

The /poll command displays a poll to (by default) all members in the server with the options provided. The command is a shortcut to open the poll creation menu.

docs.title:
Server Ban

(/sban)
docs.text:
Utility

,

Moderation

|

3

|

Added 0.1.2

| sban, server-ban, soft-ban

Unlike /ban, which bans a player from all servers, this command bans them from the specific game server the command is fired from. Players cannot rejoin that specific server, but can rejoin the universe in other servers as they please. Once the server closes, due to inactivity or shutdown, they will be able to rejoin all servers. This command does not ban the player from servers you are in, just the specific server. If you wish to ban players from all servers, use /ban.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Required  Default Description Player player nil The player you want to ban. Reason string nil The reason the player will see (filtered). Length time Forever The length the player will be banned from the server for. Moderator Note string "No note provided" What other moderators will see when looking at the bans.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• Ban
  • Temp Ban
  • Kick
  • Bans
  • Limits
  • Shutdown
  • fShutdown

docs.title:
Serverlock

(/serverlock)
docs.text:
Utility

|

3

|

Added 0.0.1

| serverlock, slock

/serverlock (or /slock) locks the server for players that are not the specified rank or higher, so /serverlock 4 would lock the server so anyone other than permission level 4 or higher will be disconnected when they try to join.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Name Type Required  Default Description Rank number 1 The minimum rank required to join the server

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
• /shutdown
  • /fshutdown

This command has no parameters.

docs.title: See Also
docs.text: • /hide-ui

Shutdown

(/shutdown)
docs.text:
Utility

|

3

|

Added 0.0.1

| shutdown

/shutdown shuts down the server with support for soft-shutdown. The server shuts smoothly and the players are re-connected to the game in another server. For the opposite effect, /fshutdown shutdowns the server within 3 seconds without soft shutdown.

Arguments: None

3

Force a player to sit down!

Send a player into the stratosphere, and potentially past it and into orbit!

docs.title:
Temporary Ban

(/tban)
docs.text:
Utility

,

Moderation

|

3

|

Added 0.1.2

| tban, temp-ban

/tempban (or /tban) is an alternative to /ban which bans the player temporarily instead of permanently, and in all servers.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Required  Default Description Player player nil The player you want to ban Reason string nil The reason the player will see (filtered). Length time Forever The length the player will be banned from the server for. Moderator Note string "No note provided" What other moderators will see when looking at the bans.

View (/view, /spectate, or /watch) allows you to view the player in-game and spectate their character. Your camera will follow them until either you or they die.

Arguments: Player : player

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: The Destrix API Module, abbreviated as DAX (or DAXM), is a specialized module designed to facilitate effortless server-side interaction and control over Destrix for scripts. DAXM is distinct from DXCA (Destrix Client API Module) and should not be conflated with it.

docs.title: Core Functionalities
docs.text:
DAXM is instrumental in performing elementary tasks including but not limited to:

  • Disabling specific commands for designated permission levels,
  • Temporarily concealing the panel for enhanced user engagement.

However, there are explicit limitations to DAXM's capabilities. It is not designed to:

  • Alter user settings or data,
  • Monitor client-generated requests,
  • Modify pre-established settings in Configurations.

docs.title: Recommended Applications
docs.text:
DAXM is optimized for enhancing User Experience (UX). Typical use cases encompass:

  • Concealing panels during transitional phases like loading screens and cinematic cutscenes to ensure uninterrupted user engagement,
  • Deactivating commands that potentially conflict with other scripts, maintaining the game’s functional integrity.

Additionally, DAXM can be employed to retrieve specific data including bans or command logs.

docs.title: Your Responsibility
docs.text:
We advocate for a conservative approach in utilizing DAXM via remote events triggered by a client. It’s advisable to initiate detection of user involvement in an event server-side, for instance, during portal entry.

In instances where the deployment of a remote event is indispensable, exercise caution to prevent any potential disablement impacts on other players. Ensure the prompt elimination of remote events associated with DAXM that are rendered obsolete or inactive.

docs.title: Our Assurance
docs.text: The incorporation of DAXM in your game is characterized by minimal risk, attributed to its confined interference with Destrix. We are committed to ensuring a seamless, secure experience. Any identified bugs or vulnerabilities can be promptly reported through destrix.app/report for expedited resolution.

docs.title: Interfacing
docs.text:
DAX is automatically launched and placed into ServerScriptService if Destrix is installed. Require the DAX module via these simple steps, with error-proofing for safety. Requiring the module is quite simple: 

local DAX = require(game.ServerScriptService:WaitForChild("DAX", math.huge())) --(1)

  1. Call WaitForChild just in-case an error occurs and DAX is delayed.

Warning

The above code will yield your entire script until DAX is initiated, which takes on average around 2-16 seconds. If DAX doesn't initialise because of an error — or Roblox is experiencing issues — your script will never load.

We recommend you to use a seperate script for DAX integration, or set up your own wrapper if your game is big.

docs.title: Calling a function
docs.text:
Calling a function is as simple as.. 

DAX.v1:FunctionHere(paramaters)
    -- handle it here
end)

docs.title: Command Types
docs.text:
Please note that these are not final and maybe be further changed.

This page contains all the command types used in Destrix. Command types are a more accurate label of commands, they are not categories.

Name Examples Description Added Limit ui-interference /hideui, /showui Commands that interfere with other game UI. 2 Jan, 2023 None character-interference-2 /kill, /fling, /sit Commands that can move, damage/kill, morph, or add animations to characters. 10 Apr, 2023 None character-interference-1 /paint, /bighead Commands that change the appearance of characters in a small way. 10 Apr, 2023 None moderation-2 /softban Small moderation commands like /softban (server bans). 10 Apr, 2023 None moderation-1 /kick, /ban Moderation commands. Can only be disabled by the Destrix system to prevent attacks. 10 Apr, 2023 0 seconds ^ server-interference /shutdown Commands that may stop servers or reboot them. 10 Apr, 2023 60 seconds * software /admins, /cmds Commands that are for using Destrix easier. Can only be disabled by the Destrix system. 10 Apr, 2023 0 seconds ^ contact /modcall Commands that allow players to interact with moderators/admins. 10 Apr, 2023 30 minutes workplace-interference /reloadmap, /reloadworkplace Commands that interfere with the workplace. 12 Apr, 2023 None prompt /promptgamepass, promptasset Commands that prompt users. 12 Apr, 2023 None teleport /fplace, /rejoin, /reconnect Commands that use TeleportService. 12 Apr, 2023 60 seconds * fun /fire, /sit, /stratosphere Commands in the category 'fun'. 12 Apr, 2023 None danger /stopmods * Commands that can stop admin commands. Can only be disabled by the Destrix system. 12 Apr, 2023 0 seconds ^ dev None Hidden developer commands. Can only be disabled by the Destrix system. 12 Apr, 2023 0 seconds ^

* Cannot be interacted with for 30 seconds after limit expires. ^ Can only be interacted with by Destrix.

docs.title:
DAX

:DisableEXEType
docs.text: DisableEXEType is the function responsible for disable commands by type. Rather than disabling individual commands, you can disable them by type. These are not the same as categories.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Default Description Command Type string Required The type of commands you want disabled. Players table? nil The players you want the commands to be disabled for. If blank, they will be disabled for all players.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
The example below will disable all of the commands that interfere with user interface not from Destrix, for all players.

DAX:DisableEXEType("ui-interference")

The example below disables all of the commands that interfere with user interface not from Destrix just for just 1 player, @DestrixApp (game.Players.DestrixApp).

DAX:DisableEXEType("ui-interference", {game.Players.DestrixApp})

This method accepts multiple users, as showcased below:

DAX:DisableEXEType("ui-interference", {game.Players.DestrixApp, game.Players.Wolf1te, game.Players.WXRobloxcom})

docs.title: DAX:FireCommand
docs.text: FireCommand lets you fire command logic for specific players artificially.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Name Type Default Description Command Name or ID string? Required The command you want to fire. You can either use the command name as a string, or the ID as a number. Players table? nil Which players will the command be fired on? Arguments table? nil A dictionary of arguments, keys and values.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
The example below will fire the command "plus," and show the Destrix Plus menu to all players.

DAX:FireCommand("plus", nil, nil)

The example below will fire the "ban" command on @WWolfite (game.Players.WWolfite).

DAX:FireCommand("ban", {game.Players.WWolfite}, {["reason"] = "Example.", ["time"] = "3600"})

docs.title: What is it?
docs.text: The Destrix Integrations API Module (DAXI) is related to DAX. It is an easy way for 3rd party software to integrate features seamlessly with Destrix.

docs.title: Interfacing
docs.text:
DAXI is automatically launched and placed into ServerScriptService if Destrix is installed. Require the DAXI module via these simple steps, with error-proofing for safety. Requiring the module is quite simple: 

local DAXI = require(game.ServerScriptService:WaitForChild("DAXI", math.huge())) --(1)

  1. Call WaitForChild just in-case an error occurs and DAXI is delayed.

Warning

The above code will yield your entire script until DAXI is initiated, which takes on average around 2-16 seconds. If DAXI doesn't initialise because of an error — or Roblox is experiencing issues — your script will never load.

We recommend you to use a seperate script for DAXI integration, or set up your own wrapper if your game is big.

docs.title: Calling a function
docs.text:
Calling a function is as simple as.. 

DAXI.v1:FunctionHere(paramaters)
    -- handle it here
end)

docs.title: Extensions
docs.text: Extensions are a great way to improve your Destrix experience for your experience. You can either create your own extensions, or you can view some extensions on the Destrix's Github. Click to view Destrix Themes, or Destrix Plugins.

docs.title: How to add a theme to Destrix
docs.text:
...

  themes = {
    "DestrixApp/snowy";
    -- (1)
    -- (2)
  }

  ...
  1. You can add your own themes here if the repo is public. {github_username}/{repo_name}
  2. You can add multiple themes, but this may cause compatibility issues.

docs.title: Endorsed Extensions
docs.text: Endorsed Extensions are currently in BETA. Report any issues at https://destrix.app/report.

docs.title: Additional Structure
docs.text:
Add additional information to your extension. Compatible with plugins and themes.

Info

This page assumes you have set up a repository for either a theme or a plugin.

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text:
Add a changelog to your extensions.

WithWithout

Adding/creating your own changelog is as simple as adding changelog.json to your repository. An example below is how your changelog.json file should look: 

{
    "changelog_manifest_version": 1,
    "version": "1.0",
    "last_updated": "2023-11-18T08:38:55Z", // (1)

    "entries": [
        {
            "version": "0.9",
            "date": "2023-11-18T08:38:55Z",

            "title": "Log Name",
            "subtitle": "View the changelog",

            "summary": "Your full summary here. You can use basic markdown if you wish." // (2)
        }
    ]
}

  1. Confused? This date is in ISO 8601 format. (e.g. {year/yyyy}-{month/mm}-{day/dd}T{hour/hh}:{min/mm}:{sec/ss}Z)
  2. We support limited markdown for changelogs. We support # as well as ##, **bold text**, _italics_, ***bold and italic text***, ~~strike through~~ but not nested italics, tables, or anything else.

docs.title: Introduction to Making Plugins
docs.text:
Plugins are an awesome way to increase the efficiency of Destrix for your experience. Sometimes Destrix may not have a functionality you or your admins/mods want. To fix this, you can either create your own plugin (in this tutorial) or browse some of the already existing plugins.

Responsibility

Plugins are uncontrolled and can pretty much do anything with your experience. To reduce risk, please make sure you trust the plugins that you are inserting and do not add plugins that other users tell you to. It is safe, however, to assume the plugins that are endorsed on DestrixApp are safe to use.

Destrix is not liable for the damage caused to you, your users, or your experience due to a malicious extension.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: You can add a theme to your experience anytime. However, to become an endorsed theme, your theme must adhere to the Destrix Theme Guidelines. You're theme also has to abide by the Roblox Community Guidelines and Roblox Terms Of Service. For safe keeping, please follow the guidelines reguardless. However, all themes must abide by the Destrix Extensions Security Policy.

docs.title: Create a new theme
docs.text:
To create a theme,

  1. Open Github (or create an account),
  2. Go to Home, and next to "Top Repositories," click "New"
  3. Under repository name, set it as anything.
  4. Ensure the repository is public, and create it

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
(Mainfest V1)

Destrix will look for your manifest.json file, which contains all the information about your extension, click here for more information for a valid manifest.

docs.title: Supported Files
docs.text:
• manifest.json
  • main.luau: Initiates after Destrix is fully loaded.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
.
├─ manifest.json
├─ main.luau
...

docs.title: Built-in variables
docs.text: • none

docs.title: How it works
docs.text:
Your script is loaded via loadstring and parented to ServerScriptService.

Limitations

Plugins can not use DataStoreService, loadstring, require(), or getfenv (nor setfenv).

Additional Settings

Want to add a changelog or more? Check out the Additional Structure reference.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This section is still being worked on.

docs.title: Introduction to Making Themes
docs.text: Themes for Destrix are a way to personalize Destirx for your experience, or your own theme for others to use.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text: You can add a theme to your experience anytime. However, to become an endorsed theme, your theme must adhere to the Destrix Theme Guidelines. You're theme also has to abide by the Roblox Community Guidelines and Roblox Terms Of Service. For safe keeping, please follow the guidelines reguardless. However, all themes must abide by the Destrix Extensions Security Policy.

docs.title: Create a new theme
docs.text:
To create a theme,

  1. Open Github (or create an account),
  2. Go to Home, and next to "Top Repositories," click "New"
  3. Under repository name, set it as anything.
  4. Ensure the repository is public, and create it

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
(Mainfest V1)

Destrix will look for your root.css file, which contains all the settings and information for your theme.

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
Themes use limited CSS currently. We use these variables: 

:root {
  --destrix-main-bg-color: #111216; /* (1) */
  --destrix-main-fg-color: #1F2024; /* (2) */
  --destrix-main-text-color: #FFFFFF; /* (3) */
  --destrix-main-text-accent-color: #DCDCDC; /* (4) */

  --destrix-main-success-color: #6FF796; /* (0) */
  --destrix-main-error-color: #DC3545; /* (0) */
  --destrix-main-warning-color: #FFC107; /* (0) */
  --destrix-main-info-color: #0381FF; /* (0) */

  ...
}

  1. This is the main color used for the Destrix background. Light: #NONEDark: #111216--destrix-main-fg-color can also be referred to as --destrix-main-accent-color

If one of these are not specified, it while default to the current value. Click the icon for the default value.

Additionally, we also use variables for the settings as well.

:root {
  ...

  --destrix-ts-base: dark; /*(1)*/
  --destrix-ts-background-img: rblxid(0); /*(3)*/

  ...

  --destrix-manifest-version: 1; /*(2)*/
}
  1. light/dark (What base does your theme use. Is it more light or more dark?)

If you want to be a lunatic and override a property via an instance name, you can doing this:

make it .overrides and a .txt file or even .env ffs idgaf

docs.title: Theme Guidelines
docs.text:
This page contains all the current guidelines that endorsed themes have to follow. Please note that themes are also expected to abide by the Roblox Community Standards and the Roblox Terms of Use.

Recently Updated

These guidelines have been updated as of 13 November 2023, and will be effective 6th May, 2023. View the old guidelines here.

docs.title: 1. Neutral
docs.text: Themes for Destrix must strictly adhere to a policy of neutrality and should avoid any form of controversy. They are not permitted to endorse or convey opinions on sensitive topics, reference drama, divisive events, tragedies, or any related content. Themes should maintain a neutral and inclusive stance, fostering a positive and enjoyable user experience for all without inadvertently promoting any form of bias or contention.

docs.title: 2. Security
docs.text: Your theme should not violate our Extenstion Security Policy.

docs.title: 3. Bodily Parts
docs.text: Themes are prohibited from containing or being centered around imagery related to bodily parts, including but not limited to skin, blood, waste, etc.

docs.title: 4. Copyrighted Material
docs.text: Themes must not include content without proper authorization from the creator or content in the public domain. Destrix requires legal permission for the content used in your theme, and any legal risks associated with unauthorized content are your responsibility.

docs.title: 5. Original
docs.text: Themes must be predominantly original. Avoid replicating themes from other Destrix users or copying themes from different software or websites. Ensure that your theme is a unique and original creation.

docs.title: 6. Compatibility
docs.text: Your theme must be compatible across various screen sizes to guarantee a seamless experience for all users. Destrix should function normally on all devices when your theme is in use.

docs.title: 7. Personalised
docs.text: Themes cannot be self-promotional. You are not allowed to create themes about your personal brand or product for Destrix endorsement. However, you can use such themes for personal projects. Themes about notable content creators and brands are acceptable, with the criteria for notability being content creators with over 100,000 subscribers on YouTube and 10,000 followers on Twitter.

docs.title: 8. Warnings
docs.text: If your theme contains content that may pose risks for individuals with epilepsy, you must provide a warning within a reasonable timeframe before such content appears, prioritizing the safety of users with epilepsy.

docs.title: 9. Performance Impact
docs.text: Themes should be optimized for performance to ensure they do not significantly impact the gameplay experience. Avoid excessive use of resources that could lead to lag or performance issues.

docs.title: 10. Transparency
docs.text: Provide clear information about the functionalities and features of your theme. Users should have a comprehensive understanding of what to expect when using the theme.

docs.title: 11. Maintenance
docs.text:
Endorsed Destrix themes are required to stay up-to-date with changes and respond with-in a reasonable timeframe from an update being announced that may effect your theme.

We also encourage that your theme accessible to visually impaired people, such as those with affected color sight. Please note that if your theme falls into disrepair for a long amount of time, it may be removed from our repository and no longer available.

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text: If your theme abides by these rules that does not gurantee that your theme will still be endorsed. Please note that these guidelines are also subject to change, and your theme will be removed if it violates the updated guidelines even if it was previously aloud.

docs.title: Extension Manifest
docs.text:
The extensions manifest (v1) is pratically the settings for your extension. Here are the basic keys most extensions use:

{
    "name": "Your Extension",
    "description": "Describe your new extension",
    "cover_image": "rbxassetid://0", // (1)
    "type": 1, // (2)

    "vesion": "1.0",
    "manifest_version": 1
}

  1. If you have no image set (or it fails to load) it will use the default (the Destrix logo).If you have an ID set and your image has not loaded, open Roblox Studio and insert a Decal, then past your ID as the texture, wait a few seconds, then copy the converted ID/string, replace cover_image with it, and it should then load.

  2. 1: Plugin 2: Theme

Danger

Failure to provide the following keys will result in your extension being unloadable:

  • manifest_version
  • version
  • name

Furthermore, failure to provide valid values will also result in your extension not working.

Having trouble and don't know why?

Frequent Issues

Error: "Required manifest infrastructure missing"

This error means your extension is missing a key listed above. If you think you have all of them, make sure to check if you've made a typo/mispelt one of the required keys. The position of them does not matter.

Error: "Invalid manifest version"

You have mistyped the value of manifest_version, make sure it is set to 1.

Error: "You are using a deprecated manifest version"

This error may be caused by having a mistyped value of manifest_version again.

If your error is not listed here, contact support.

docs.title: Adding author/s
docs.text:
Do you have multiple authors/contributors, or is it just you? You can add credit to your extension via the manifest by adding the following:

{
    ...

    "authors": [
        "655331725", "5230234514"
    ]
}

This also works with a single author, just simply keep one entry under the authors key.

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: Welcome to the step-by-step installation guide for the Destrix admin system. Follow these simple steps to easily integrate Destrix into your Roblox game, unlocking a world of efficiency, flexibility, and power.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure that you have:

  1. A Roblox account. Sign up if you don’t have one yet.
  2. Roblox Studio installed. Download it here if needed.

docs.title: Step 1: Visit the Destrix Page
docs.text:
• Navigate to the Destrix Page on Roblox.
  • Click on the ‘Get’ button to add it to your inventory.

docs.title: Step 2: Open Roblox Studio
docs.text:
• Launch Roblox Studio
  • Open the game you’d like to add Destrix to, or create a new one.

docs.title: Step 3: Insert Destrix into Your Game
docs.text:
• Go to the ‘View’ tab, then select ‘Toolbox’ to open the toolbox window.
  • In the toolbox, click on ‘Inventory’, then ‘My Models’ to find Destrix.
  • Drag and drop Destrix into the workspace. It will automatically configure itself.

docs.title: Step 4: Test the Installation
docs.text:
• Click on ‘Play’ to enter the game simulation mode.
  • Use a Destrix command (e.g., !help) in the chat to verify the successful installation.

docs.title: Configurations
docs.text:
"What does this one do?"

Settings can be overwhelming, with so many options, it's easy to get lost at some point. If you ever forget or don't know what a setting does, refer to this guide to understand it! This will hppefully make certain you don't break anything.

This documentation is incomplete. Please come back later.

docs.title: Default Ranks
docs.text: Rank Name Permission Level Commands Common Use Creator 6 All Commands Typically reserved for the creator of the game/group, or co-owners that you trust with full access. Developers 5 /fshutdown For developers of the game, admins and moderators will not need these commands. Admins 4 /shutdown, /ban Administrators will be able to Moderators 3 /tban, /sban, all "Fun" commands Privileged 2 Cosmetic commands VIP 1 Cosmetic commands, (self only) NonAdmin 0 Software commands and other harmless commands like /rejoin.

docs.title: Introducing Destrix
docs.text:
Destrix is a concept I've been thinking about of quite some time now. I realised that most admin panels aren't crafted for large games, and how I wanted something that would be universe and allow use in small, medium, and even large games on Roblox.

Finding motivation is tough with a project this daunting, so I decided to write some documentation in advance to get my thoughts out there, it's quite fun!

...

docs.title: Destrix Plus Enterprise
docs.text: Destrix Enterprise is a subscription that will elevate your entire experience/s. If the owner of a game (or group owner) has Destrix Enterprise, every moderator will receive Destrix Plus benefits. Starting at 14.99/month.
